11:11 am
BE

Grey incoming.

BE

The long-awaited inflection point in the Fed cycle is imminent. Our economists
expect 100bps cumulative rate hike by end-2016. We believe that UK
international and Swiss banks (notably UBS) stand most to benefit from higher
USD yield curves. French banks have also typically performed relatively well,
benefiting from USD-denominated earnings.

BE

How did European banks perform through US rates inflection?
The 1994 and 2004 cycles provide two differentiated reference points. Unlike
1994, we believe that the current cycle is much better telegraphed even if
there remains a debate on the pace of rate hikes. History would then favour
the USD earners – the French and UK internationals.
UK International & Swiss banks geared to higher interest rates
Although most European banks are largely exposed to European yield curves –
which we expect to be ‘lower for longer’ in the context of extended QE – the
UK international and Swiss banks have significant exposure to the USD curve.
Our economists forecast 100bps rate hikes by the end of 2016, including a
25bps liftoff in Dec 2015, albeit with ‘only’ 20bps at the long-end ie bear
flattening scenario. In such a context, we estimate a c7% profit upgrade
potential at UBS and c5% at CS and HSBC.
Macro trading should benefit from higher volatility
Higher US rates could have a mixed impact on sales & trading revenues.
While macro business (namely rates & FX) are typically price-agnostic and
benefit from higher volatility, credit-sensitive products tend to be more
directional. Amongst the major European wholesale banks, Barclays remains
most biased to macro, including a geographical slant to US and UK. UBS
should also benefit given its G20 FX bias. By contrast, Credit Suisse’
exposure to credit, emerging markets and securitized products could drive
greater volatility, in the context of our strategists expectations of further
widening of credit spreads.
Valuation and risks
The sector is down 4% YTD and trades on PTBV 2016E 1.00x for ROTE of
9.9%. Key upside risks include: higher rates, faster pick-up in credit growth
and sovereign spread tightening. Key downside risks, especially for our top
pick picks, include persistently low inflation and an even longer low-rate cycle,
weak economic rec

11:12 am
BE

... overy, and credit risk in commodities and emerging
markets exposures.

BE

.......... Or to phrase it another way.

BE

The interest rate sensitivity of the European banks in our coverage to US rates
largely depends on the geographic footprint (US and countries with USD-linked
exchange rates). UBS, Credit Suisse, HSBC and Standard Chartered are likely
to have the highest interest rate sensitivity in our coverage. Investment banks
are indirectly exposed to interest rates, largely via potentially higher customer
activity in the global Macro business (namely Rates and FX).
Generally banks are more exposed to the shorter-end of the yield curve
therefore disproportionately benefit from a bear flattening (short end led). US
curves have already been trending this way with our rates colleagues
expecting a much more pronounced flattening by 2016 with c.100bps uplift at
the short end and only a modest c.20bps increase at the long end.

We use the current financial market indicators (USD:ZAR at 16 and bond yields at
10.5%) to extrapolate an implied 'alternative' scenario from our current UBS base case
– i.e. what we would derive for the SA economy in 2016 from the current financial
market indicators. We base our simulation on historical sensitivities and relationships,
and believe the result would be: GDP growth of more like c0.5-1%, CPI of 7.3%,
Interest rates of 8.5% (16E yr-end), a budget balance of -4.5% and higher public debt
(50-51% of GDP).

BE

Goldman double upgrade.

BE

Consensus forecasts too high but no downside left in the shares, they say.

BE

Which is the most dangerous of analyst calls.

11:29 am
BE

It's a 2016 preview piece, so runs on for several hundred pages. Here's the first of them.

BE

Goldman on utilities

Key 2016 themes: 1) gas price downside; 2) restructuring upside
and 3) growth niches, incl. renewables and environment
We expect: 1) lower gas prices to lead to lower earnings in power
generation, gas supply/LNG trading and E&P activities; 2) upside from
sector restructurings, as corporate break-ups increase focus on a SOTP
approach. We also expect M&A to pick up and now include M&A
components in valuations for 9 stocks. 3) Although we forecast almost no
growth in the sector, we see significant growth niches such as wind
manufacturing with a 14% 2015-19E EPS CAGR and Veolia/Suez with 12%.

BE

Lower gas prices to lead to SSE dividend cut - Conviction List-Sell
We expect SSE’s EPS to fall 15% between FY15-20, with headwinds from
lower commodities offsetting growth from its regulated networks and new
renewable capacity. We forecast a material dividend cut in 2018 reflecting
an increasingly stretched balance sheet and deteriorating credit metrics.

Restructuring and consolidation: CL-Buy E.ON, Acciona and Hera
We believe E.ON’s break-up plan and Acciona’s plan to sell the real estate
business will crystalize upside to a SOTP approach which we estimate to
be 100% for E.ON and 42% for Acciona. Both stocks are CL-Buy. We also
expect progress on consolidation of the Italian local utility industry which is
supportive for the growth outlook of Hera (CL-Buy) and A2A (Neutral). For
Hera we remain 7%-16% above Reuters consensus 2016-17 EPS forecasts.

11:30 am
BE

Rerating to continue for wind manufacturers: Vestas CL Buy
We forecast a 14% 2015-19 EPS CAGR for wind turbine manufacturers
driven by strong wind installations and operating leverage. We prefer
Vestas (CL Buy) on valuation grounds and we see the potential extension
of the US subsidies before year end as the next catalyst.
Double upgrade for Drax: Risk/reward skewed to the upside

We upgrade Drax to Buy from Sell: We believe the risk/reward is skewed to
the upside following underperformance (-53% ytd vs. our coverage +5%).
Our new 260p 12-m PT implies 16% upside potential and we see only 3%
downside with more bearish assumptions on price for biomass conversion.
We upgrade PPC to Neutral from Sell after underperformance.

BE

As always with Goldman, it's been written for a cyborg rather than a person to read.

PM

cruel

11:30 am

BE

11:31 am
BE

It's as if it's written to be machine read, as if they're speaking direct to the Marshall Wace machines rather than the fund managers.

BE

And I'm not going to argue with that approach because clearly, Goldman know more about the value of research than me.

BE

Anyway, here's the bit of the Drax sum that's been written for a human.

11:32 am
BE

Catalyst
The key question for Drax is the European Commission (EC)’s decision
on whether to approve a fixed price contract for difference (CfD) for
Drax’s planned conversion of its third unit to burn biomass (from coal),
and if so, at what price. Our forecasts and valuation assume the
contract is approved at a price of £100/MWh (vs. £105/MWh proposed;
all prices in 2012/13 money). We see positive read-across from the EC’s
recent decision to approve a £105/MWh price on a similar contract for
RWE’s plant at Lynemouth. We expect a decision on the CfD from the
EC in the next 12 months.

Shell could walk away, they could seek to change terms or shareholders could vote the deal down. Those are the options. The break fee on the deal is pretty low. So I think shell will come under pressure over the next few months to say how is this deal going to work, because it doesn’t work at the current share price. The current share price of Shell and the price they are paying for BG. I am not going to comment on what we are going to do just short term.

11:41 am
BE

Here's Barclays.

BE

@Pharma, indeed, apologies.

BE

Overnight Royal Dutch Shell received unconditional approval from Chinese Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) for the combination with BG. This marks the final regulatory approval and fifth pre-condition that has been met. The next stage is now for the publication of shareholder documentation ahead of the shareholder votes. Assuming that both sets of shareholders vote in favour of the deal, it is possible that the transaction could now be completed by the end of January or mid-February compared to our initial assessment of end March. Although the spread between the BG share price and implied offer price has widened in recent weeks we see the comments by Shell CEO Ben Van Beurden, that “This is a strategic deal that will make Shell a more profitable and resilient company” as further evidence, if it was needed, as commitment to the deal by Shell even in a weaker oil price environment. We rate both stocks Overweight and with BG shares trading at just over a 9% discount to the implied offer price, we see BG as a discounted way of entering the combined company. On a 12-month basis Royal Dutch Shell remains our Top Pick within the European Integrated Oil Sector and we rate the stock Overweight with a 2750p/sh price target.

Spread has widened to 9%: Shell’s offer for BG when it was announced in April was set at 383p of cash and 0.4454 Shell shares for every one BG share, although the theoretical BG price does also need to be adjusted for the quarterly dividend that the Shell shareholders receive compared to the semi-annual payment from BG. On our calculations this leaves the spread between the implied BG price and the actual BG share price as 9.2% which is down from highs of 13% in August but up sharply from the 6% discount that the shares were trading at when the previous approval was received. We see the spread continuing to narrow in the run-up to the deal closing in early 2016.

11:43 am
BE

Go on ....

PM

A RUSSIAN billionaire has quietly built a large minority stake in Petropavlovsk, fanning speculation that he could launch a bid for the gold miner chaired by City veteran Peter Hambro.

Viktor Vekselberg, whose net worth is estimated at $12bn, controls a vast empire through his holding company Renova. In recent weeks it has used three subsidiary companies — Lamesa Group, Lamesa Foundation and Polo Company— to amass a 20% stake in Petropavlovsk, owner of one of Russia's largest gold mines.

Renova did not return calls.

Petropavlovsk — founded 21 years ago and originally called Peter Hambro Mining — declined to comment.

The move by Vekselberg, 58, owner of a 250ft super-yacht called Tango, is the latest development in a harrowing year for Petropavlovsk.

The miner nearly went bust when it was unable to meet repayments on more than $900m of debts. It had spent heavily to develop a large deposit in eastern Russia amid a crash in the price of the precious metal. From a peak of nearly $1,900 an ounce in 2011, it has dropped to about $1,076.

Petropavlovsk was saved by a deeply discounted £155m rights issue in February that wiped out shareholders who chose not to throw more money at the company. The deal included a new $100m (£65.7m) bond convertible to stock.

BE

That's the broker, not my opinion. They're turning over the old IHG story.

11:50 am
BE

Which has been heard about as often as the Sky story in recent weeks, but remains entirely without proper sourcing for the moment.

BE

Here's Oddo's argument.

BE

Three hotel deals following the same logic: boost market share in a segment or geographic region

In 2015, Marriott acquired Starwood, Jin Jiang-Louvre Hotels and Accor-FRHI. These three
deals seem different but we see a common point: market share gains in specific segments or
geographic regions. The quest for critical mass vs alternatives (OTAs, Google, AirBnB) is
probably still the best-possible response even though we do not think that this solves the
problem in the medium term. Especially since the announced synergies are still relatively
modest. The first two transactions went through at between 11.4-11.9x EBITDA while the
Accor-FRHI merger was over 20x (like IHG-Kimpton).

11:51 am
BE

Who's next? IHG seems to be the main target in Europe

In the European vista, we can probably rule out at a deal involving Rezidor (Rezidor is
mainly held by US group Carlson). The same goes for NH Hotels given the weight of its main
shareholder HNA (29.5%). Melia's future is tied to that of the Escarrer family while
Whitbread's near-exclusive focus on the UK probably reduces its speculative appeal (except
in the scenario of a spin-off of Costa Coffee). Accordingly, IHG becomes the ideal target for
an M&A deal.

IHG: what advantages does the group present?

IHG has significant market share: i/ in the US with 480,000 rooms in 2015e, i.e. 65% of its
base and 72% of its EBIT; and also ii/ in China with 90,000 operated rooms (60,000 in the
pipeline). These two markets are the largest ones in the world. The group's pipeline also
comes to 218,000 rooms, i.e. 29% of the existing network, giving growth potential for the
existing base of over 3% per year. IHG has the advantage of a portfolio of powerful brands,
particularly the Holiday Inn family. With 90% of its business derived from fees, IHG also has
a recurring and defensive profile combined with strong free cash-flow generation. Finally, its
balance sheet is an obvious strength - the group is on course for finishing 2015 with an
estimated net debt/EBITDA ratio of 0.7x vs guidance for 2.0-2.5x, giving potential excess
cash of around $ 1.5bn (16% of the group's current market cap).

BE

Who would the predator be? With or without a Chinese player? With or without Accor?

Hyatt does not seem to be in a position to finance a deal of this kind despite the obvious fit.
Hilton could be a possibility in spite of the relatively significant brand overlap in the midscale
and extended-stay segments. This leaves the potential harboured by Chinese players, as
recently highlighted by Jin Jiang, or a Chinese sovereign fund. Finally, IHG and Accor
HotelServices would provide a strong geographic fit with "local" brands boasting a strong
reputation, but we think that the acquisition of FRHI pushes back this scenario by two or
three years.

Buy recommendation maintained: an unjustified valuation discount

IHG's fundamentals are still robust with EPS growth expected in the double digits for 2014-
2017e and the significant support provided by the potential cash return to the shareholder.
The valuation is appealing with 2016e P/E of 20.5x, a 2016e EV/EBIT of 12.7x and a
discount vs Accor (15.2x post FHRI), WTB (14.3x) and US peers (14.0x). Moreover, IHG
enjoys best-in-class status in margins and ROCE.

BE

And sorry about the messy formatting.

11:52 am
BE

We've heard a lot that there's something happening in the hotels sector, though that's never not true.

BE

See Arash's story last week about Accor, for instance: http://www.ft.com/...-4812f209f861.html

PM

11:53 am

11:55 am

BE

It's true that Shire does seem to be talking to Baxalta. Though if it weren't considering a raised offer it would've had to have told us, so Bloomberg's story on Friday was slightly state-the-obvious-y.

BE

Shire continues to repeat that it might walk.

11:56 am
BE

If you want Barclays numbers on this, here they are.

BE

A penny for your thoughts. Bloomberg reported Friday (11/12) night that Shire is reportedly to hold talks that may lead to a deal for Baxalta. Bloomberg also states that the offer may include cash versus the initial 100% equity offer. The timing may not be coincidental as after 6m the tax rules regarding spin outs are relaxed potentially allowing Shire to shift the offer towards cash. Our view remains unchanged that a Baxalta acquisition is a means to an end but a sensible one as it would open options previously not available to Shire (further deals in the orphan and specialty area) and as it helps addressing a number of patent expiries post 2020.

It seems reasonable to assume that the next offer would have to be above the initial implied $45.23 offer price. As we wrote in our recent Shire upgrade (21 September 2015), we believe that an offer price up to $55/share makes sense and in that note we outlined a 0-28% accretion scenario. A lot has happened since then, not least the continuous refusal of the Baxalta board to cooperate and also the poor Shire share price performance. The latter clearly had an impact on the potential accretion levels of the proposed acquisition and the company’s desire to inject cash into the deal ahead of the proposed buy back would make sense to us. Regardless, a successful deal would help bridge the post-2023 revenue gap opened by the Vyvanse patent expiry.

We are not blind to the potentially changing dynamics in the Haematology market (Roche’s ACE910) but the potential $1bn cost savings target (24% of Baxalta OPEX) outlined in our Shire upgrade makes this an acceptable risk, as does the potential upside form the plasma business Shire would acquire. Overall our view remains unchanged – the market is overly focused on the hemophilia risk and is missing the bigger picture. A successful deal would re-focus Shire’s valuation on the near-term growth as well as the continuing shift to rare diseases with the accompanying multiple benefit.

BE

Is it me, or does this all feel a bit choreographed?

Tribal warned that profits in 2015 will be significantly lower than expected as sales momentum continued to be slow and a number of key contract milestones have moved into 2016. Discussions are being held with its debt providers to negotiate amendments to the operation of covenants and the waiver of any event of default that may result from current trading. In this regard, the Board is proposing a £35m rights issue in Q1’16 of which £30m is fully underwritten on a standby basis. This year has been a perfect storm for the group; the re-shaped Board has taken the necessary steps to strengthen the balance sheet so it can move forward with its strategy. Steps are being taken to simplify and streamline operations, increase focus on its cloud strategy and ensure stronger account management. It is making good progress on its CEO search. We are putting our forecasts under review; with the £30m+ of recurring support revenues to provide valuation support.

The explanation for the shortfalls is customer programmes which have made slower progress than expected. The result was cost-rises and delayed revenues. Delays in relation to the SALM programme in New South Wales is flagged in the update – while activity levels recovered following the renegotiation of SALM in October, new work orders have not yet engaged fully in some cases.

Given the current uncertainties, we are placing our recommendation under review. Our new forecast for the current year (FY2015E) is £3.5m PBT (£5.5m prior) 2.9p EPS (4.5p prior). This would equate to c.£10m of EBITDA (£12m prior), lending colour to the need to adjust covenants re-finance, given a 3x EV/EBITDA covenant.
